verses.text: A slothful \add man\add* is compared to a filthy stone, And every one will hiss \add him\add* out to his disgrace.
A slothful \add man\add* is compared to the filth of a dunghill: Every \add man\add* that takes it up will shake \add his\add* hand.
An evil nurtured son \add is\add* the dishonour of his father that begat him: And a \add foolish\add* daughter is born to \add his\add* loss.
A wise daughter shall bring an inheritance to her husband: But she that liveth dishonestly \add is\add* her fatherâ€™s heaviness.
She \add that is\add* bold dishonoureth \add both her\add* father and \add her\add* husband, But they both shall despise her.
A tale out of season \add is as\add* musick in mourning: But stripes and correction of wisdom \add are\add* never out of time.
Whoso teacheth a fool \add is as\add* one that glueth a potsherd together, \add And as\add* he that waketh one from a sound sleep.
He that telleth a tale to a fool speaketh to one in a slumber: When \add he\add* hath told \add his\add* tale, he will say, What is the matter?
If children live honestly, and have wherewithal, They shall cover the baseness of their parents.
\add But\add* children, being haughty, through disdain and want of nurture Do stain the nobility of their kindred.

Weep for the dead, for he hath lost the light: And weep for the fool, for he wanteth understanding: Make little weeping for the dead, for he is at rest: But the life of the fool \add is\add* worse than death.
Seven days \add do men\add* mourn for \add him that is\add* dead; But for a fool and an ungodly \add man\add*, all the days of his life.

Talk not much with a fool, And go not to him that hath no understanding: Beware of him, lest thou have trouble, And thou shalt never be defiled with his fooleries: Depart from him, and thou shalt find rest, And never be disquieted with madness.
What is heavier than lead? And what \add is\add* the name thereof, but a fool?
Sand, and salt, and a mass of iron, \add is\add* easier to bear, Than a man without understanding.
\add As\add* timber girt and bound together in a building cannot be loosed with shaking: So the heart that is stablished by advised counsel shall fear at no time.
A heart settled upon a thought of understanding \add Is\add* as a fair plaistering on the wall of a gallery.
Pales set on a high place will never stand against the wind: So a fearful heart in the imagination of a fool cannot stand against any fear.
He that pricketh the eye will make tears to fall: And he that pricketh the heart maketh \add it\add* to shew \add her\add* knowledge.
Whoso casteth a stone at the birds frayeth them away: And he that upbraideth \add his\add* friend breaketh friendship.
Though thou drewest a sword at thy friend, \add yet\add* despair not: For there may be a returning \add to favour\add*.

If thou hast opened thy mouth against thy friend, fear not; For there may be a reconciliation: Except \add for\add* upbraiding, or pride, or disclosing of secrets, or a treacherous wound: For, for these \add things\add* every friend will depart.

Be faithful to \add thy\add* neighbour in \add his\add* poverty, That thou mayest rejoice in his prosperity: Abide stedfast unto him in the time of \add his\add* trouble, That thou mayest be heir with \add him\add* in his heritage: For a mean estate \add is\add* not always to be contemned: Nor the rich that is foolish to be had in admiration.
\add As\add* the vapour and smoke of a furnace \add goeth\add* before the fire; So reviling before blood.
I will not be ashamed to defend a friend; Neither will I hide myself from him.
And if \add any\add* evil happen unto me by him, Every one that heareth \add it\add* will beware of him.
Who shall set a watch before my mouth, And a seal of wisdom upon my lips, That I fall not suddenly by them, And \add that\add* my tongue destroy me not?
